Fig. 1 Time course of the formation rates of CO (determined by IR) and H2O (determined by MS) under cyclic unsteady-state RWGS (cyclic feed of 2 % CO2, 6 % H2), followed by steady-state RWGS (co-feed 2 % CO2 + 6 % H2) reaction at 325 °C over In2O3-15 (0.020 g) in a fix-bed reactor. Fig. 2 (A) Temperature dependence of the CO formation rates for the unsteady-state and steady-state RWGS reactions. (B) Relationship between the steady-state and unsteady-state RWGS rates over different type of In2O3 at 325 °C. Conditions: 2% CO2, 6% H2, He balanced. Fig. 3 Arrhenius plots for RWGS reaction over different type of In2O3: (A) steady-state (0.050–0.110 g) and (B) unsteady-state (0.020 g). Condition: 2% CO2, 6% H2, He balanced. Fig. 4 Reaction order of CO2 and H2 for steady-state RWGS reaction over In2O3-15. Conditions: 6% H2 and 1–6% CO2 for the CO2 order; 2–8% H2 and 2% CO2 for the H2 order; 0.020–0.100 g catalyst. Fig. 5 (A) UV-vis spectra of In2O3-15 (0.020 g) after O2-oxidation and after H2-reduction at 350 °C. (B) H2O formation rates (MS) and ΔKM versus the time during the reduction under 6% H2/He at 350 °C. The extinction coefficient for the In+-□ species was calculated using the ΔKM at 600 nm and the integrated amount of H2O formed based on the following stoichiometry: H2 + In3+-O → H2O + In+-□. Before the measurement, the sample was successively pre-exposed to 6% H2 (350 °C, 2000 s) → He (350 °C, 300 s) → 2% O2 (350 °C, 600 s) → He (350 °C, 1200 s). Fig. 6 Operando UV–vis results for In2O3-15 (0.02 g) during the unsteady-state RWGS reaction at 325 °C: (A) representative spectra, (B) the difference spectra with respect to the spectra at t = 0 s, and (C) time course of the H2O and CO formation rates, concentration of In+-□, and the formation rate of In+-□ (Δ[In+]/Δt). The ΔKM was converted to the concentration of In+-□ using the extinction coefficient estimated in Fig. 5. Conditions: 2% CO2, and 6% H2. Fig. 7 Redox mechanism for RWGS reaction over In2O3-15. Fig. 8 (A, B) Changes in the In K-edge XANES spectra of In2O3-15 under unsteady-state and steady-state RWGS reaction conditions at 325 °C. (C) Time course of cumulative amount of formed CO and the energy at μ = 0.6 during re-oxidation in 10% CO2 after reduction by 30% H2 for 1000 s at 325 °C. Fig. 9 LCF analysis of the representative spectra during operando XANES experiment: (A) H2-reduced In2O3-15 (t = 0 s) and (B) CO2-reoxidized In2O3-15 (t = 1000 s). (C) Time course of cumulative amount of formed CO and concentration of In3+ during re-oxidation in 10 % CO2 after reduction by 30% H2 for 1000 s at 325°C. Graphical abstract The catalytic activities of In2O3 catalysts with different surface area for both cyclic unsteady-state (transient) and steady-state reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reactions were systemically investigated. The initial CO formation rates during CO2-oxidation of the H2-reduced In2O3 catalysts were close to the CO formation rates in steady-state RWGS conditions at 325 °C, suggesting a redox mechanism for the steady-state RWGS reaction over the In2O3 catalysts. Transient kinetics for the In3+/In+ redox and products (H2O, CO) formation during the cyclic H2-reduction and CO2-oxidation of In2O3 under periodic feeding of H2 ↔ CO2 were studied by time-resolved operando UV–vis and In K-edge X-ray absorption experiments at 325 °C. During the H2-reduction, the surface In3+-O species was reduced to produce H2O and In+-□ (□: oxygen vacancy). Subsequent re-oxidation of the In+-□ by CO2 gave CO and the In3+-O species. The transient CO formation rates were close to the consumption rates of In+-□ under CO2, providing a quantitative evidence on the redox mechanism for unsteady-state RWGS reaction over In2O3. These results indicate that the unsteady-state and steady-state RWGS reactions are primary driven by the In3+/In+ redox mechanism. Kinetic results show that the reoxidation step is the rate-limiting step in the steady-state RWGS reaction. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Reverse water–gas shift reaction Indium oxide Operando spectroscopies Redox mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogenation of carbon dioxide (CO2) into valuable chemicals, such as methanol (CH3OH), carbon monoxide (CO), and olefins, has been recognized as a promising approach to attaining carbon neutrality.[1,2] The reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction (CO2 + H2 → CO+H2O) has been studied for CO2 conversion to CO, which is a valuable feedstock for the synthesis of diverse chemicals via Fischer-Tropsch or other syngas processes.[3] Transition metal and noble metal catalysts have been studied as effective catalysts for the RWGS reaction.[4–11] Recent attentions have been focused on the development of non-conventional catalysts for RWGS reaction.[10] As an example, In2O3-based catalysts are attracted much attention as alternative catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and RWGS reaction.[12–22] Despite considerable research efforts on the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation over In2O3-based catalysts,[19,23] the mechanism of RWGS reaction over In2O3-based catalysts is not clear. The mechanism has been discussed based on theorical evidences,[15,23] but spectroscopic evidences are limited.[24–26] Moreover, the spectroscopic studies conducted are not combined with quantitative kinetic analysis, without correlating the spectroscopic results with the products analysis,[24–26] thereby failing to identify the true active sites. For instance, Liu et al. applied in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy and density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation over In2O3.[23] They suggest that the RWGS reaction mechanism on the In2O3 involves the direct dissociation of CO2 over oxygen vacancy sites to produce CO,[23] but the proposed redox mechanism is not supported by direct experimental evidences. Redox and/or associative mechanism have been proposed in the literature for the RWGS mechanism and still a matter of debate for In2O3.[19] Earlier works by Otsuka demonstrated cyclic unsteady-state water gas shift (WGS) reaction by In2O3 catalysts, in which H2O was reduced by the CO-reduced In2O3 to yield H2.[27–30] Based on the detailed kinetic results, the authors proposed that the reduced In species and oxygen vacancy sites play an important role in decomposition of H2O to yield H2. This implies that cyclic unsteady-state WGS reaction by In2O3 catalysts can be driven by redox mechanism. Although, the redox mechanism for RWGS and WGS reactions over In2O3 has been proposed based on calculation and experimental results, to our knowledge, there only are a few operando spectroscopic evidences on the redox mechanism. Among a few studies, Hess et al. employ in situ/operando and ex situ spectroscopy to investigate the dynamic of In2O3 surface and bulk phase during RWGS reaction.[25] They proposed that the rate-limiting step is the activation of CO2 to CO over reduced In2O3 surface. In the previous studies of RWGS mechanisms over reducible metal oxide catalysts, in situ/operando spectroscopic techniques play a crucial role.[31–36] X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis), and Raman spectroscopies have been utilized for investigating the reduction/oxidation of the metal sites,[13,31–36] while infrared (IR) spectroscopy has been utilized for identification of adsorbates (formate/carbonate/carboxylate).[31–35] In our previous studies on the WGS mechanism on CeO2-supported metal catalysts (Au/CeO2 and Cu/CeO2), we demonstrated comprehensive operando spectroscopic studies that combines quantitative analysis of Ce4+/Ce3+ redox rates and rates of gas phase products formation using operando UV–vis.[31,32] This approach allowed us to directly compare the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox rates and the products formation rates. In this study, we show that the RWGS activity over different types of In2O3 in unsteady-state conditions is close to that in steady-state conditions in the temperature range 300–350 °C. Based on this observation, operando UV–vis and XANES experiments under periodic feeding of H2 ↔ CO2 are conducted to investigate the reaction mechanism. The results show that the unsteady-state and steady-state RWGS reactions are primary driven by the In3+/In+ redox mechanism. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation In2O3-15 was synthesized using a precipitation method as outlined in the literature.[37] Specifically, In(NO3)3 hydrate (Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical Co.; purity of 99.9%) was dissolved in a mixture solution containing 48 mL of deionized water, 48 mL of ethanol (99.9%), and 36 mL of dilute NH4OH solution (25 wt% in H2O). An additional 108 mL of ethanol was then added to this mixture to induce precipitation. The resulting product was aged at 80 °C for 10 min, filtered, and washed with deionized water until the pH reached 7. The powder was dried overnight at 110 °C and subsequently calcined in flowing air at 400 °C for 5 h. In2O3-9 (99.995%) and In2O3-5 (99.9%) were supplied by US Research Nanomaterials, Inc. and Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical Co. The catalysts are designated here as In2O3-X, where X represents the specific surface area (m2 g−1), and it is used solely for the purpose of distinguishing the samples without any other significance. 2.2 Characterizations Operando diffuse reflectance UV−vis experiments were performed with a JASCO V-750 UV−vis spectrometer, linked to a mass spectrometry (MS) detector (JEOL, JMS-Q1500GC). 20 mg of the catalyst powder was positioned in a diffuse reflectance cell (JASCO HISV-728 in Figure S1) with a quartz window, and the inlet of the cell were connected to a gas flow system. Reflectance data were converted to pseudo-absorbance using the Kubelka–Munk (KM) function. Background spectra were gathered using BaSO4.[31,32] Outlet of the cell was connected to IR (gas cell) and mass spectrometry (MS) which were used for the analyses of the outlet CO and H2O, respectively. CO and H2O concentrations were estimated with the calibration results for CO and H2O. Before in situ/operando UV–vis measurements, the sample was pretreated under 10% O2/He at 400 °C for 0.5 h. Typical conditions for the operando UV–vis are as follows: 2% CO2 and 6 % H2 in He with total gas flow rate of 100 mL min−1. N2 adsorption analyses were conducted using an AUTOSORB 6AG instrument (Yuasa Ionics) at 77 K, yielding data utilized for determining the specific surface area via the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Before N2 adsorption tests, the sample was pretreated under H2 (1200 s) → CO2 (1800 s) → H2 (1200 s) → CO2 (1800 s) at 325 °C to obtain the stable surface area of In2O3 after the unsteady-state RGWS reaction. In K-edge XANES spectra were acquired in transmission mode at the BL01B1 station with a Si(311) monochromator located at SPring-8 (JASRI) on a home-made quartz cell (Figure S2) with 40.5 mg sample, Japan, under Proposal No. 2023B2096. Typical reaction conditions are as follows: 10% CO2 and 30% H2 in He with total gas flow rate of 300 mL min−1. The concentration of the outlet CO was detected by MicroGC (JMS-Q1500GC) and estimated with calibration results by standard curve of CO. XANES spectra were quantitatively analyzed by linear combination fitting (LCF), where the unknown spectra were linearly fitted with experimental XANES standards using least-squares fitting. In2O3 (In2O3-9) and In foil (Spring-8) were used as standards to LCF the spectra of In2O3-15 during XANES by using Athena software. The fitting window was set to 27925–27975 eV, and the fitting space was norm μ(E). After the LCF analyses, the weight of In2O3 (α) and metallic In (β) for the fitted spectra were obtained. The percentage of In3+ (Fig. 9C) is calculated by In3+/(In3++In0) = α/(α + β) × 100 %. The average oxidation state (AOS) of In species (Figure S16) is calculated according to following formula: AOS of In = α × 3 + β × 0. The In3+ concentration (η; mmol g−1) is calculated by the following formula: η (mmol g−1) = α × 1/(277.64 g mol−1) × 1000, 277.67: molar mass of In2O3. Operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) was carried out utilizing a JASCO FT/IR-4600 instrument equipped with a DRIFT cell containing 50 mg of powder. Online IR (gas cell) and MS (JEOL, JMS-Q1500GC) were used for the analyses of the outlet CO and H2O, respectively. Before DRIFT measurements, the sample was pretreated under 10% O2/He at 400 °C for 0.5 h. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic tests were performed in a fixed-bed flow reactor (Pyrex tube with a 4 mm inner diameter) using 20 mg of catalyst. Typical reaction conditions are as follows: 2% CO2 (99.995%, Taiyo Nippon sanso Co.) and 6% H2 (99.99%, Tomakomai Hydrogen plant) in He (99.995%, Westfalen) with total gas flow rate of 100 mL min−1. The concentrations of CO and CO2 were measured with an online IR spectrometer (JASCO FT/IR-4600, TGS detector, 20 scans), equipped with a home-made gas cell featuring CaF2 windows. MS detector was used for the analyses of the outlet H2O based on the calibration result. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic and kinetic experiments As shown in Figure S3, X-ray diffraction (XRD) shows that In2O3-9 and In2O3-5 consist of a highly crystalline c-In2O3 structure, while In2O3-15 consists of an amorphous form of c-In2O3 with a = b = c = 10.118 Å (JCPCS: 06–0416).[37] The catalytic activities of different types of In2O3 catalysts (In2O3-15, In2O3-9, and In2O3-5) for the cyclic unsteady-state RWGS reaction at 325 °C in a flow reactor were tested (Figs. 1 and S4-5). CO2 (2%) and H2 (6%) were alternately fed to the catalyst, and the time course of the outlet concentration of CO and H2O were measured by using online IR and MS, respectively. The initial exposure of the pre-oxidized In2O3 to H2 resulted in large H2O formation owing to the reduction of In2O3 fully pre-oxidized by O2. The subsequent feed of CO2 to the reduced In2O3-x led to the formation of CO with a small amount of H2O. The second H2 feed resulted in the formation of CO and H2O. Then, the second CO2 feed to the H2-reduced sample resulted in the formation of CO only. After the second cycle of the H2/CO2 feed, an increase in the number of redox cycles did not markedly change the CO and H2O formation profiles. This indicates that the cyclic unsteady-state RWGS over three types of In2O3 catalysts is a reversible and reproducible process at 325 °C. To study the effect of temperature on the RWGS catalytic activities on different types of In2O3, the CO formation rates at 300 and 350 °C under the unsteady-state conditions (Figures S6-11) were also tested. The maximum CO formation rate under the third CO2 feed corresponds to the initial rate of CO formation for the cyclic unsteady-state RWGS reaction. After three cycles, we measured the steady-state rates of CO formation (RWGS reaction rates) under 2% CO2 + 6% H2 (Fig. 1 and S4-11). Furthermore, the steady-state rates of CO formation under 2% CO2 + 6% H2 were also tested for 1 h at each temperature. The steady-state rates in Figure S12 for the three types of In2O3 at each temperature were close to those observed after the three cycles. The initial CO formation rates at 300, 325 and 350 °C under unsteady-state and steady-state conditions for the three types of In2O3 catalysts are summarized in Fig. 2 . For the three different types of In2O3 catalysts, the CO formation rates in the steady-state RWGS reaction were the close to the initial rates of CO formation under the unsteady-state conditions at three temperatures. Increase in the surface area of In2O3 resulted in the increase in the rates in the order In2O3-15 (15 m2 g−1) > In2O3-9 (9 m2 g−1) > In2O3-5 (5 m2 g−1). The rates for the three In2O3 catalysts under steady-states at 325 °C are plotted versus those unsteady-state conditions in Fig. 2B. Clearly, a linear correlation between the steady-state and unsteady-state rates is observed with a slope of unity. This indicates that the transient CO formation during the re-oxidation of the H2-reduced In2O3-x with CO2 accounts for the steady-state catalytic activity of the In2O3 for RWGS reaction. The Arrhenius plots for the steady-state RWGS reaction over In2O3-15, In2O3-9, and In2O3-5 catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 A. The Arrhenius plots for the cyclic unsteady-state RWGS at 300, 325, and 350 °C (based on the initial CO formation rates under the third CO2 feed) are also shown in Fig. 3B. Both the CO formation rates for the steady-state and the unsteady-state RWGS reaction increase with increase in the surface area of the In2O3 catalysts. For both the steady-state and the unsteady-state RWGS reactions, the apparent activation energies (E a) decrease with increase in the surface area of the In2O3 catalysts. Hereafter, the most active catalyst, In2O3-15, was adopted as a model catalyst to explore the RWGS mechanism. Interestingly, the E a values for the steady-state reaction are close to those for the unsteady-state reaction for all of the In2O3 catalysts. Combined with the linear relationship in Fig. 2B, this result demonstrates that the transient CO formation during the re-oxidation of the H2-reduced In2O3-x with CO2 accounts for the steady-state RWGS activity of the three different In2O3 catalysts. Fig. 4 shows the reaction orders with respect to CO2 and H2 for the steady-state RWGS reaction at 300, 325, and 350 °C. At the tested temperatures, the reaction orders of CO2 are around 1, which is higher than the H2 orders (around 0.5). This result suggests that the reaction rates for the RWGS on In2O3-15 show a stronger dependence on the partial pressure of CO2 than that of H2. In other words, the dissociation of CO2 is the rate-determining step in the steady-state RWGS reaction over In2O3-15. 3.2 Operando UV–vis studies for unsteady-state RWGS The mechanisms for the steady-state RWGS and WGS reactions, discussed in the literature, can be categorized into the redox and associative mechanisms.[31–33,35] The results discussed above suggest that the steady-state RWGS reaction over the In2O3 catalysts is dominantly based on the redox mechanism where the re-oxidation of the H2-reduced In2O3-x with CO2 is the main CO formation step. In our previous work, the mechanism of WGS over CeO2-supported Au and Cu catalysts have been systemically investigated by quantitative kinetic analyses of operando UV–vis results.[31,32] Based on the fact that the reduced In2O3-x catalyst shows a characteristic UV–vis feature,[38] here we adopted the operando UV–vis spectroscopy to verify the redox mechanism for the RWGS reaction over In2O3. Assuming the redox mechanism, the cyclic unsteady-state RWGS activities of In2O3 (Fig. 1) are explained as follows: the In3+-O species on In2O3 are reduced by H2, producing H2O and forming oxygen vacancies (□) adjacent to the In+ species (In+-□ species). These In+-□ species are then reoxidized by CO2, generating CO and regenerating the In3+-O species. Operando UV–vis experiments during the reduction half-cycle (RHC) and oxidation half-cycle (OHC) were conducted to verify this redox hypothesis. Referring to the calibration method employed in our prior investigation,[31,32] we determined the extinction coefficient for the In+-□ species as follows. In Fig. 5, we present the in situ UV–vis spectra of In2O3-15 before and after the reduction at 350 °C in 5% H2/He for 2000 s in a diffuse reflectance cell (JASCO HISV-728 in Figure S1). After the reduction, a broad visible absorption band attributed to the In+-□ species was observed.[38] Quantification of the H2O generated during the reduction was accomplished through MS detector. Subsequently, we estimated the extinction coefficient for the In+-□ species using the total H2O produced and the UV–vis intensity increase (ΔKM) at 600 nm, as detailed in the caption of Fig. 5. Fig. 6 illustrates the operando UV–vis results obtained during the unsteady-state RWGS reaction over In2O3-15. The time course of products formation during operando UV–vis (Fig. 6) shows the same kinetics as the results from the flow reactor (Fig. 1), except for the lower activity in the diffuse reflectance cell due to its poor mass transfer. The catalyst underwent alternating exposure to 6% H2 ↔ 2% CO2 (with a 100 s He purge between H2 and CO2) at 325 °C, while monitoring the in situ UV–vis spectra. Concurrently, the outlet concentration of CO and H2O was measured by IR and MS detector, respectively. Fig. 6A exemplifies the UV–vis spectra of the pre-oxidized (0 s), H2-reduced (1200 s), and CO2-reoxidized (2400 s) samples. Fig. 6B illustrates the difference spectra relative to the spectrum of the pre-oxidized In2O3-15 (0 s). The H2-reduction of the pre-oxidized catalyst gave a broad band in a range 500–800 nm due to the In+-□ species, and the band intensity was decreased by the subsequent reoxidation under CO2. Fig. 6C illustrates the time course of the gas formation rates alongside the concentration of In+-□, estimated using ΔKM at 600 nm and the extinction coefficient. Note that the formation rates of CO are lower than those depicted in Fig. 1, possibly due to the variances in reactor configurations (Pyrex tube vs in situ UV–vis cell). Exposure of the pre-oxidized In2O3-15 to H2 resulted in the generation of gas-phase H2O and the appearance of the In+-□ species on the In2O3-15 catalyst. Subsequent exposure of the H2-reduced catalyst to CO2 led to the CO formation, accompanied by consumption of the In+-□ species. Under the second H2-reduction, the H2O formation and regeneration of the In+-□ species were simultaneously observed. These results provide direct evidences on the redox mechanism for RWGS reaction over the In2O3 catalyst. The initial rate of CO formation under CO2 (OHC) was much higher than that under H2. Combined with the kinetic results (Fig. 2B) that the CO formation rates in OHC are consistent with the steady-state rates, the result indicates that OHC is the main CO formation step for the catalytic RWGS reaction by the In2O3 catalysts. The formation rates of In+-□ were calculated through numerical differentiation of the In+-□ concentration (Δ[In+-□]/Δt). During the second H2 feed, the initial rate of H2O formation was close to the initial rate of In+-□ formation. During the first and second CO2 feeds, the initial rates of CO formation were the same orders of magnitude as the initial rates of In+-□ consumption (height of the negative peaks). Combined with the result in Fig. 2B, these results quantitatively demonstrate that the RWGS reaction over the In2O3 catalyst is driven by the redox mechanism, which shown in Fig. 7 . The initial rates of In+-□ consumption under the first and second CO2 feeds are lower than the initial rates of In+-□ formation under the second H2 feed, indicating that the dissociation of CO2 to CO in the OHC is the rate-determining step, which is consistent with previous report.25 Combined with the steady-state kinetic result (Fig. 4) that the reaction order for CO2 are larger than that of H2, it is concluded that the oxidation of In+-□ by CO2 is the rate-determining step for the steady-state RWGS reaction over the In2O3 catalyst. To gauge the uncertainty in the redox rates in Fig. 6C, we conducted reproducibility tests by estimating the initial formation rates of CO and the initial Δ[In+]/Δt values for the unsteady-state RWGS reaction at 325 °C over In2O3-15 under operando UV–vis conditions three times. The results of these tests are illustrated in Figure S13. As summarized in Table S1, the average formation rate of CO is 0.592 ± 0.028 μmol g−1 s−1, while the average consumed Δ[In+]/Δt values under CO2 is 0.43 ± 0.079 μmol g−1 s−1. These results underscore the robust reproducibility of the transient rates in the unsteady-state RWGS reaction under operando UV–vis conditions. As demonstrated by the kinetic result in Fig. 1, the RWGS on In2O3-15 is not purely driven by a redox mechanism at 325 °C, as CO is produced under RHC. To study non-redox mechanisms involving adsorbed carbon-containing species (so called associative mechanism), operando DRIFT experiment was conducted at 325 °C (Figure S14). Exposure of the catalyst to CO2 resulted in the formation of monodentate carbonate (1508 cm−1 [39] and 1371 cm−1 [40]) and bridged bicarbonate species (1308 cm−1)[40]. Subsequent exposure of the catalyst to H2 resulted in complete consumption of the carbonates within 150 s, while CO formation was observed even after the complete consumption of the carbonates. Thus, we have no spectroscopic evidences on the CO formation via a surface carbon-containing species. We propose that RWGS reaction over In2O3-15 at 325 °C is driven by both redox (main route) and associative mechanisms (minor route), but we report herein spectroscopic evidences only on the redox mechanism. 3.3 Operando XANES studies Fig. 8 show the results of the operando In K-edge XANES experiments (on a home-made quartz cell in Figure S2) during the reoxidation of the H2-reduced In2O3-15 under 10% CO2 at 325 °C. The XANES spectra of the O2-oxidized, H2-reduced, CO2-reoxidized sample and the spectrum under 10% CO2 + 30% H2 (steady-state) are depicted in Fig. 8A-B. Compared with the spectrum of O2-oxidized sample, a low energy shift was observed for the H2-reduced sample, indicating the reduction of In2O3 by H2. A high energy shift was observed in the XANES spectra during CO2 reoxidation, indicating the oxidation of the reduced In species by CO2.[24,26] Fig. 8C shows the time dependence of the energy at μ = 0.6 and the cumulative amount of CO formed (GC analyses). The kinetic curves for the cumulative amount of CO and the energy at μ = 0.6 are close to each other. The time dependence of the In3+ species was estimated by LCF analysis of XANES spectra using Athena software based on the In2O3 and In foil standard samples (Fig. 9). The LCF analysis for the H2-reduced (t = 0 s) and CO2-reoxidized (t = 1000 s) samples are shown in Fig. 9A-B. The XANES of the H2-reduced sample consists of 64.3% In3+ and 35.7% In0. Based on these values the average oxidation state (AOS) of In species was calculated to be +1.93, corresponding to the In3+/In+ ratio of 46.4%/53.6% (details are shown in Figure S16). In a similar manner, the AOS (+2.08) of the CO2-reoxidized sample gave the to the In3+/In+ ratio of 53.3%/45.7%. As shown in Fig. 9C, the kinetic curves for the cumulative amount of CO and the increase in the fraction of In3+ species are close to each other. The total amount of CO formation during OHC (0.306 mmol g−1) is close to number of In3+ sites increased under CO2 (0.187 mmol g−1). These results give quantitative evidences on the re-oxidation of the In+-□ species by CO2 to yield CO and In3+ species, which is consistent with the operando UV–vis result. Thus, the redox mechanism based on the operando UV–vis results is supported by the operando XANES results. 4 Conclusion Based on the quantitative operando spectroscopic analysis, we have concluded that the periodic unsteady-state RWGS reaction over bulk In2O3 catalysts operates predominantly via a redox mechanism. The kinetic results suggest that the steady-state RWGS reaction by the In2O3 catalysts is also driven by the redox mechanism (main route). In the reduction half-cycle (RHC), one In3+-O specie is reduced by H2 to give the In+-□ and H2O. In the subsequent oxidation half-cycle (OHC), the In+-□ site is oxidized by CO2 to regenerate the In3+-O sites, accompanying the formation of CO. The OHC, i.e., the oxidation of In+-□ by CO2, is the rate-determining step for the steady-state RWGS reaction over the In2O3 catalysts. In the context of carbon neutrality, this research can provide guidance for designing new In2O3-based catalysts for CO2 chemical utilization. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic activities of In2O3 catalysts with different surface area for both cyclic unsteady-state (transient) and steady-state reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reactions were systemically investigated. The initial CO formation rates during CO2-oxidation of the H2-reduced In2O3 catalysts were close to the CO formation rates in steady-state RWGS conditions at 325 °C, suggesting a redox mechanism for the steady-state RWGS reaction over the In2O3 catalysts. Transient kinetics for the In3+/In+ redox and products (H2O, CO) formation during the cyclic H2-reduction and CO2-oxidation of In2O3 under periodic feeding of H2 ↔ CO2 were studied by time-resolved operando UV–vis and In K-edge X-ray absorption experiments at 325 °C. During the H2-reduction, the surface In3+-O species was reduced to produce H2O and In+-□ (□: oxygen vacancy). Subsequent re-oxidation of the In+-□ by CO2 gave CO and the In3+-O species. The transient CO formation rates were close to the consumption rates of In+-□ under CO2, providing a quantitative evidence on the redox mechanism for unsteady-state RWGS reaction over In2O3. These results indicate that the unsteady-state and steady-state RWGS reactions are primary driven by the In3+/In+ redox mechanism. Kinetic results show that the reoxidation step is the rate-limiting step in the steady-state RWGS reaction.
